reviewText:
This game is simply unique. A Multiplayer Online Battle Arena in its most strict sense (if not the most traditional), you and your team have one and only objective: surviving the enemy team and slaughtering it.
Bloodline Champions bears a nearly infinite competitive potential that is often sadly overlooked because of the mistakes of its publisher and developer team, which do not seem to invest enough in the stability of this shiny, hidden gem. The community is mostly unusually nice (compared to your average MOBA - you can't expect *everybody* to be nice on the internet, can you?) if somewhat sparse in numbers.

The peculiarities of the gameplay lie in the total lack of randomly generated numbers, the importance of tactics, the interesting diversity of the characters and last but surely not least, the extreme fast pace of the game, which makes quick decision-making, knowledge of the game and instinct and reflexes key factors to prevail.

It is worthy of notice how despite it being a free to play, there is no obligement to buy anything in order to be good at it - the progression system can be slightly accelerated at the very start, but due to the extremely skill-based nature of the game, the ephemeral advantages make no considerable part in the winning: this one is most assuredly not a pay to win. Most of the buyable features are merely cosmetical and those that aren't, are always purchasable with the in-game, generously earned currency.

I guarantee you, you have never played anything quite like it. If you can resist the initial frustration of a hard-to-learn game and the occasional lag due to the developers' (hopefully temporary) lack of dedication, you'll have an experience you will not forget.

reviewText:
TL;DR: BLC is an awesome game and you should try it, but it used to be more awesome and I'd like to bring that back with your help.

BLC, BLC, where do I start with you?
I played this game from very early on, back when the game was brand spanking new and advertised as the one true PvP arena game where only skill mattered. The one game you could pick up and play without having to spend several weeks of grinding for levels or runes/masteries in order to actually start being competitive. In theory, a team of new players who were just completely at home with the game as soon as they started could beat a top competitive team who had played the game religiously half a year in advance.

And it was glorious.

Of course such a situation rarely happened. Since skill was all that mattered, veteran players were almost always set to win over newcomers, but it was as it should be. Those moments where I as a relatively new player were able to out-manouver players who were obviously better than me are memorable even to this day. The free Bloodline rotation was satisfactory and the fact that you could try them all out in single player vs bots is something I for my life cannot understand why every single F2P online game has done as well. That particular move is a stroke of genious.

Every Bloodline feels and plays differently. The only time it feels bad playing a particular Bloodline is when you're being outperformed by another which leads you to wanting to try that one instead. That is the beauty of the game. Nothing stops you from learning every single Bloodline in comfort and privacy against bots. No fees, no need to purchase the Bloodline. This means that if you were willing to put time and effort into learning the Bloodlines in-and-outs, you could prepare yourself to stand an even better chance when playing against real people. And really, Hard mode bots are way more difficult than many players!

There's practically always been a leveling system. Your level, however, was mostly just a measure of how long you've been playing the game. It had no impact on the game what so ever. What really mattered was your rank, which showed at what skill level you belonged (again, skill was all that mattered as advertised). It's important to note that at this time, it was also advertised that you could obtain most every single thing in the shop, even cosmetic items like skins, weapons and emotes, with the use of Blood Coins as well as Gold Coins, the former being the currency you earn by playing and the latter being the one you purchase with real money. Sure, the Blood Coin prices were discouragingly steep, but it really helped me customizing my one favorite Bloodline (Psychopomp btw) with some cool, non-standard gear and emotes.
The only few items that were only purchasable with Gold Coins at this time was things like the Replay system that only very serious and competitive player had any real use for.

Every single thing with this game, at that time, was geared toward easing newer players into this awesome community and experience. Stunlock knew in their heart that few people would start the process of grinding another game for points, levels, masteries and runes in order to be competitive when they've most likely invested their time heavily in other games. What they did, supplying a theoretically even playing field for new and veteran players alike, was game design ingenuity pure and simple.

FunCom however never had that much faith in the game, and it was horribly undermarketed. This is a story most of us familiar with BLC before Steam know of.

The fact of the matter is that when Stunlock introduced traits, medallions and masteries into the game, they deviated from their very own core design philosophy. When this new system, trait points unlocked by leveling and heavy Blood Coin investments in crystals and medallions hit Live, they lost a capital h Huge part of the loyal playerbase. The game, suddenly, wasn't new player-friendly anymore. Because when you tried to introduce your friends into the game in this state, all they saw was another huge time sink they had to fill in order to even have a chance. Skill was still central to the gameplay, of course, but the entire sight of the traits and nigh-mandatory medallions that you had to fill was daunting and off-putting. Suddenly, BLC seemed to be on the way of becoming every single other PvP game by mimicking the competition, when its one biggest appeal was its differences from them.

I'd rather just keep playing League

reviewText:
Bloodline Champions is hands down the best venue for displaying player skill through accuracy, dexterity, intelligence, spatial awareness, teamplay, and knowledge. It'll ask you to execute pitch perfect combos via your abilities, aim them true (everything's a skillshot), weight in the benefits of your situation and adapt on the fly, coordinate with your team down to the second, and most importantly, learn every little detail about every bloodline in order to best counter it. Barring Quake and CS, you won't find a better title to test yourself as a gamer - BLC will flex absolutely every important gaming muscle of your being and give you the grounds to prove your worth.

It should be mentioned that as of the last few days the game is now being fully operated by Stunlock Studios - the actual creators of BLC - which is certainly a step up from its previous publishers who were seemingly running it down the ground with poor marketing and cheesy design implementations. Some time ago the progression system was accelerated, the bloodcoing yield increased, and the cost of bloodlines decreased - meaning you can now more easily acquire things in the game, including the much dreaded amulets and gems to slot. The benefits from leveling and statting up were always very marginal, but were the cause for much ire back in the day, for no good reason. Do try to disregard any people saying that the game is ♥♥♥♥ solely because there's a progression system - it is an annoyance at worst and if you're dedicated you won't care for them past setting your own builds.

The playerbase might not be very large, but it's a very dedicated bunch, which is why you'll often run into people with thousands of games and hours under their belts. During the past few years I haven't played that much myself, but made an effort to log in every once in a while to check out activity, and it's always a pleasure seeing several channels still filled up with players to this day - alongside the weekly tournaments still running with dozens of teams taking part. It's a sad defect of modern gaming communities to declare games as dead based on a seemingly random set of factors like whether they found a game within a minute after queueing up at 4 AM or something of that sort, but I can guarantee you that as far as competitiveness goes, you'll find a very healthy scene, that has miraculously endured through Funcom's mistreatment during the years.

Today, with most regional locks gone, and (hopefully) with Stunlock maybe putting some life back into the game via content updates, I can see BLC emerging back into the mainstream, for as long as people are willing to give it a chance and stick around.

reviewText:
As far as I can remember, this is the first time I've reviewed a game on Steam. That's not because I'm new to Steam. It's because this game holds a place in my heart that no game has before or since. And I've played many, many games.

Bloodline Champions is the purest PvP game that has ever been. It is so unique in that sense that there is literally no game out there like it. People will compare it to other games using terms like MOBA, which will invariably conjure images of massive maps with jungles, rivers, monsters and all the things that artificially infuse what we have come to think of as MOBA's with their complexity and depth.

But BLC doesn't need any of that. Its depth comes naturally, as a result of its actual complexity. BLC is what a MOBA should be: an arena in which players do battle--not one in which players level and shop and kill little monsters until they are ready to do battle. There is no avoiding battle in BLC. And when it happens, it's determined entirely by the skill of the player on the keyboard.

There is a lot to say about BLC. Perhaps, the most important thing to say is that it's a shame that one of the worst game publishers in existence got its hands on what you can tell is the work of a passionate development team. But I'm eccstatic to see what appears to be a revival now that Stunlock has taken it back.

In the mean time, if you are reading this and thinking about playing Bloodline Champions, this player couldn't possibly give a more sincere endorsement. If you like PvP, you absolutely must try BLC.

reviewText:
This game requires a HUGE amount of skill. Legitimate skill. You need to know your bloodline and a lot of esoteric information in order to even get by in this game.

I've played since shortly after post-beta and I bought most of the characters I wanted back then, and I maxed out my level and all my stats and have nothing to worry about... but for people joining now, you're going to have to either pony up some cash or play for a long time before you can unlock all the bloodlines you may want to play, the minmaxing medals and stat slots, etc.

This game is PLAY2Win, meaning the more hours you have put into the game the better you'll be at it. The upgrades you get from leveling up make you strictly and objectively better than someone who has just started out, so new players WILL start at a disadvantage.

It's an extremely fun game if you're willing to put in time and effort, but it can be discouraging at times.

I of course strongly recommend it (and I'm always looking for people to play it with) but I also strongly suggest that you understand what you're getting into before you join up. There's not a huge influx of new users daily like other more popular free2play games, so you may very well be a small fish in a very large pond.

It's hard to get into, but once you're into the game it's the most fun and addictive game I could ever recommend to somebody.

Love PvP?
Like arena style combat?
Don't like the length of DotA/LoL games?

This game is for you.
Bloodline Champions, is a moba style game with a cast of 16 + heroes, or bloodlines. Matches are set in 3v3 format and take usually no more than 5-6 minutes.  There are 4 archetypes of classes, Tanks, Melee, Ranged, and Healers, each with a set of unique characters within them. There are no minions, no farming, just a 3v3 slaughter fest where skill triumphs all. I'm not going to go too deep here, its better for you to experience this thing yourself.

There are two very large issues with this game. The first, would be the severe latency spikes and or, even total game freezing. Stunlock has not, as of 3/6/15, not given any sort of comment on the matter, which seems to be a lot more common than you would think.

You'll still find matches, but theres a good chance you'll be playing against some vets that have been playing for a very long time. If you find yourself getting beat in actual pvp matches, go against the bots.  I can't stress this enough.They're surprisingly well done and are very good for getting the hang of your chosen bloodline.

So, come, play a few rounds, bring your friends. Revitalize this game. Don't allow the one unique MOBA out there to go off into that silent night.

reviewText:
Short Summary:
Bloodline Champions is an a-typical experiment in the MOBA genre that manage to transcend the overused formula with true innovations and skill based gameplay. Highly recommended to people who wants a different MOBA experience and aren't afraid of investing the time in a hardcore skill-based game. For the casual gamer I would say BLC would pose too much of steep learning curve and a lot of frustration of losing to veteran players.

Extended Review
Been playing this game since early beta, clocking hundreds of hours before the integration to steam so I thought I should give a review of what I consider to be one of the best MOBA games out there, which sadly doesn't get the recognition it deserves.

Bloodline Champions (BLC) isn't your typical garden variety MOBA, in fact it so different that some people don't consider it a MOBA at all because it isn't stylized after DOTA and its clones, but since MOBA is Multiplayer Arena Battle - BLC fits the bill.

What you'll instantly notice is the FPS-driven (top down perspective), WASD movement, mouse-target aiming, heavily skill-based mechanics that aren't to be found in most MOBAs today. A good FPS gamer would have an easier time learning to master the different champions in the game.

The 2nd quite noticeable thing is the lack of lanes, creeps or a base for that matter - did I mention that this isn't DOTA?! - if you cut all the fat from a DOTA game, leaving it with just the characters, their abilities and how they work together in a team you'll get BLC. This is a clash of your team with the opponents team without anything interfering - no RNG, no creeps, no turrets. It's just kill or be killed. There are no levels or items, so all of the micromanaging (which I hate honestly) in other MOBAs and best builds" is out of the window - the cards you're dealt comes with your chosen champion and don't change during the match

reviewText:
Match length in Bloodline Champions is short, relative to other games in the genre. Rather than spending an hour or longer hoping for a game to finally come to an end, matches are often decisively ended within 20 minutes. There are outliers that drag on beyond 40, as evenly matched teams may have trouble managing to end the game against one another, but the game's rapidly scaling death timers generally enable one team to end the competition before that point is reached. Usually, games are over quickly enough that you'll convince yourself you always have time for one more game.

If you wish to shine individually, you may not enjoy Bloodline Champions; the game is very team-centric, to the point that even experience is shared across an entire team--all players on the same team are the same level during a match. An individual's power to affect a match is limited. Grouping up is essential to winning matches, and attempting any sort of heroic 1-vs.-5 play will likely be met with death. This serves to reduce the amount of rampant toxicity the genre is rather notorious for bringing; most game and chat experiences feature very few instances of nasty epithets, and with cross-team chat disabled outright, there is no opportunity for insulting opponents.

The environments, animations, and sounds of combat all evoke a mental investment in the action. Animations are simultaneously flashy and elegant, and ability animations feature enough clarity that it's rare to be confused about what killed you. Gunners gun crackles and flashes for each enemy it hits. As Flameman The Flame God leaps into the fray from across the map, a burning fire signals his landing. The comical Ranid Assassin mounts up into its longboat when activating a heroic taunt (unlockable for $10), and he sings a merry tune as he shoots his darts. And the sound of a dead hero (with which you will become very familiar) features a bass shoomp" to draw just the right amount of satisfaction for each and every kill your team secures.

League of Bloodstorm Champions is a must-play for both MOBA players and Blizzard enthusiasts. It avoids stepping into the exact footprints of the games that paved the way for the genre
recommended: unique experience with familiar characters. And should you not fall into either category
hoursPlayed: it is still a fantastic casual-competitive game that offers untold hours of enjoyment."

reviewText:
A game that I once claimed was the best competitive game I ever played. I played this game for countless hours before it came to steam and I loved it.

That being said, this game was ruined in development. Each hero used to feel very unique, but balance patches made a lot of characters a lot less fun than they used to be (Seeker, Glutton, Blood Priest to name a few).

And the nail in the coffin - the talents/gems/medallion system. Back when heroes had a static amount of health and these numbers were low - about 150 to 200 health - the game was much better. You knew if an enemy used an ability, it would be a certain amount of time before it came back off cooldown. Now with the wonky stat system you can never tell their cooldown, their movement speed or how much damage they are going to do. Game feels very pay to win and was practically abandoned with no updates from the old studio.

This used to be an amazing game, and you might still enjoy it if you didn't know it in its former glory. But regrettibly I cannot recommend it anymore.

reviewText:
I have played Bloodline Champions when it came out, but it felt pretty uneven and unbalanced. The tragedy is, while they may have did a lot to balance the champs and eradicate bugs, they were simply too late. When it came out, LoL, HoN Dota were the main mobas and drew a lot of attention. While the idea of Bloodline champions is nice, there is little beginners playerbase imho. Games you play as a beginner are either vs ridiculously stronger opponents (e.g. having weeks or months on their profile) or...hm... no you always play vs stronger opponents. i tried it at various times, opponents were always way stronger and more experienced. I cant even blame it on the matchmaking because there is none for beginners. Simplay put, you either have already played the game, or go through a long and tedious period of learning, constantly getting owned with little success moments to motivate you. Apart from that, the champs are not all free to play. Another disadvantage considering the small hero pool.

tl;dr
if you consider getting this game, dont, you are too late. Let it rest in piece as a pioneer moba idea that came at the wrong time.

reviewText:
This is a pretty cool concept. I initially was interested in this game by the unique concept and was captivated by it. After playing it for a few hours the concept starts to lose it's initial appeal and you're left with the actual gameplay which to be honest is pretty good. The gameplay is fun and fairly well put together and balanced. I will say that much like any team based game the players can ruin games for you and make it a hell however that doesn't make the game itself bad.

My only real problems with the game are the difficulty to buy a new bloodline and the grade system. The grade system seems to be pretty unique but not in a good way. Unlike a typical mmr system that most competitive games have this game has a grade system which gives you a grade based on how well you played ranging from 1-25. This would be fine except for starters it doesn't really explain how it gives you a grade very well and it took a bit of research to get a general idea how it worked. From my research I believe it gives you a grade based on your maximum achieved scores which is a pretty lame way to do it rather than using an average. The other problem is that it takes a fair amount of time to farm up enough to buy a new bloodline but I guess that isn't really that bad so I won't say don't play because of that. The player base is also a little low so sometimes finding games can be a bit of a hassle but that can easily be changed.

They do a lot of tournaments that any team can qualify for simply by signing up which I think is a fantastic idea and more games should implement this. The tournaments reward the winners with certain prizes that let them get special reqards. The tournaments also range in skill level so that you aren't playing with a grade 2 and a grade 25 in the same game, they try and even it out so that you can play in tournaments with people of your own skill level. They also have a ranked system so that you can achieve certain ranks for the season and get little rewards for that as well.

All in all this is a good game for killing some time and certainly worth a look. Check it out and I hope this review helped you!

reviewText:
This is a pretty cool concept. I initially was interested in this game by the unique concept and was captivated by it. After playing it for a few hours the concept starts to lose it's initial appeal and you're left with the actual gameplay which to be honest is pretty good. The gameplay is fun and fairly well put together and balanced. I will say that much like any team based game the players can ruin games for you and make it a hell however that doesn't make the game itself bad.

My only real problems with the game are the difficulty to buy a new bloodline and the grade system. The grade system seems to be pretty unique but not in a good way. Unlike a typical mmr system that most competitive games have this game has a grade system which gives you a grade based on how well you played ranging from 1-25. This would be fine except for starters it doesn't really explain how it gives you a grade very well and it took a bit of research to get a general idea how it worked. From my research I believe it gives you a grade based on your maximum achieved scores which is a pretty lame way to do it rather than using an average. The other problem is that it takes a fair amount of time to farm up enough to buy a new bloodline but I guess that isn't really that bad so I won't say don't play because of that. The player base is also a little low so sometimes finding games can be a bit of a hassle but that can easily be changed.

They do a lot of tournaments that any team can qualify for simply by signing up which I think is a fantastic idea and more games should implement this. The tournaments reward the winners with certain prizes that let them get special reqards. The tournaments also range in skill level so that you aren't playing with a grade 2 and a grade 25 in the same game, they try and even it out so that you can play in tournaments with people of your own skill level. They also have a ranked system so that you can achieve certain ranks for the season and get little rewards for that as well.

All in all this is a good game for killing some time and certainly worth a look. Check it out and I hope this review helped you!

reviewText:
I have over 1000 hours in this game. It wasn't always on steam.
Fast, furious, intense. Entirely skill based, 3v3 arena combat.
A match typically lasts only 5 minutes.

Think of this game as a MOBA, where everyone is already max level, has a full build of items, and are already positioned for a teamfight... This is where a match of BLC begins, and also where the similarities end. Because this game is so focused on the intensity and fast paced action of those teamfights, it goes above and beyond anything you've ever encountered before. Magic bolts flying everywhere, explosions all around you, split second juking and dodging, careful timing, focus, and precision.

Simple enough layout/gameplay that you can pick it up in 20 minutes.
But, a ridiculously high skill cap means you can always do better.
Top down, WASD to move. Each character has 6 basic abilities, 2 special abilties, 1 ultimate.
Every ability is a skillshot. You have to actually aim to hit things. Every time you hit things, you gain energy which can be spent to cast your special abilities for a small amount or your ultimate for a much larger amount.

It's free to play, and I can not recommend it enough. Funcom drove the playerbase into the ground, but they have since been removed, and the players have come back in droves. It only takes a minute for matchmaking to find people for a game now. (Perhaps longer for new players that have no in-game rating yet.)

In-game tournaments every other day (which cater to even low skill players, so everyone can join in!) with great rewards.


As a free to play, there's some things we have to cover:
Q1) How long does it take to grind a new character to play?
Less than any other f2p game I've ever played. Between a large daily coin boost pool, really short match times with high rewards, low cost characters in the shop, and two quests unlocking a character each for free, there's just no comparison. There are 27 characters to choose from, all free to play/try against bots before picking one up in-game.

Q2) How's the real world $ to in-game currency rate?
First, you can unlock every single character (all 27) for $20. So that's insane.
Second, those in-game tournaments reward you with coins for skin unlocks/etc. So that's awesome too. Third, the devs give out free skins/avatars/titles on holidays just for logging in, which is unheard of in f2p games. Otherwise, if you wanted to buy a cosmetic with regular cash, it has about the same going rate as other f2p's out on the market. So, there's lots of freebies and character unlocks are super cheap, but cosmetic items are of usual prices.

Having said that, a healer can own anything if played properly!

reviewText:
This game is good but not great.

My friend and I were browsing through steam to find a decent free multiplayer game that we can play.
And so we found this.

Bloodline Champions is a multiplayer arena fighting game where you can select various types of 'bloodlines' to play as.
The main gamemode is typically 3v3, but you can have 5v5, and play with different gamemodes and maps.

I've only played a couple of hours with this game, but from what i've seen i find it pretty enjoyable.
PROS:
+ lots of different bloodlines and playstyles to choose from
+ Colourful art style and smooth graphics
+ Different combos/attacks each bloodline can perform (also there is an epic ultimate move!)
+ Fast paced and short rounds.
+ Great for playing with friends
CONS:
- Can be a bit chaotic and confusing at times
- Alot of the cosmetics cost real money (but that doesn't effect the gameplay).
- The virtual currency (gold) is over priced.

Overall the gameplay is great, but most (if not all) the cosmetics for your bloodlines cost gold (virtual currency).
6.5/10

this is by far the best pvp oriented game I have ever played. It has a few short commings that I will address as well.

cons.

- win traders
-long matchmaking times....
- lack of updates or content
-lack of players
-lack of players who are willing to practice and quit
-complainers....


That out of the way lets touch on the pros. This game will not have you sitting down for hours just for one match bored out of your mind. Even when lossing it just shows you what you have to work on. As stated this game soley works on your skill. You can litterally miss (or dodge) melee attacks making your skill level determine how good you are. There are prefered team comps however you can pick whatever champions you want as long as you kill their team before they can kill yours. In this game with no chat filter they do not overly babysit you and "force you to behave." If someone is being annoying just mute them and be on your way.



Now for the cons. The poor management is probably what gets under the remaining players skins the most. You will often see people typing in channels saying " if only this game had advertising etc. etc.

Lack of updates show the blatant fact that this game is running on autopilot. Even community driven events would have a highly positive impact on the game. Win traders are a plague in this community
